s.text: The clothes do the work, the actor could be anybody.
The clothes do the work, the actor could be anybody.
Arrayed on dummies, the Versaces have the air of waiting backstage for their entrance music.
Italy had to wait until after World War II to regain its rightful status as a primary fashion source.

Richard Martin, the curator of the Costume Institute's show and author of the catalog, has stripped the Versace ensembles of the celebrity aura of their original wearers--Claudia Schiffer, Princess Diana, etc.--so that the clothes can show their own true qualities.
A black columnar dress with long sleeves and a neckline up to the chin in front leaves the whole back bare to well below the waist at one side.
A black columnar dress with long sleeves and a neckline up to the chin in front leaves the whole back bare to well below the waist at one side.
Note how the swirls of gold hit the body over the breasts, navel, and ovaries, while the leopard's spots slink over the crotch, thighs, and knees.

When he forgets the eye and the body and tries to appeal to the mind; when he blinds you with too-vivid zebra juxtaposed with too-vivid leopard so you can't see the dress; or when he overburdens the feminine torso with a short, floppy, bulky hoop skirt apparently made of hugely printed pastel silk curtains from a Las Vegas hotel room, topped by a short, bulky blue denim jacket with big brass buttons, then he starts looking too French, and by that I mean, theoretical.

When he forgets the eye and the body and tries to appeal to the mind; when he blinds you with too-vivid zebra juxtaposed with too-vivid leopard so you can't see the dress; or when he overburdens the feminine torso with a short, floppy, bulky hoop skirt apparently made of hugely printed pastel silk curtains from a Las Vegas hotel room, topped by a short, bulky blue denim jacket with big brass buttons, then he starts looking too French, and by that I mean, theoretical.

When he forgets the eye and the body and tries to appeal to the mind; when he blinds you with too-vivid zebra juxtaposed with too-vivid leopard so you can't see the dress; or when he overburdens the feminine torso with a short, floppy, bulky hoop skirt apparently made of hugely printed pastel silk curtains from a Las Vegas hotel room, topped by a short, bulky blue denim jacket with big brass buttons, then he starts looking too French, and by that I mean, theoretical.
The face is left to do its work alone.

There we see his imagination working with mobile combinations of expanded and unearthly human creatures, covered with color and pattern and accompanied by music, not so very far from the desired effect in much of real life right now.

What does embrace both the modern and the body, by contrast, is Versace's sleek, stiff, short hoop-skirt dress made of briskly clashing silk-print sections in color, swept with a flowing black-and-white silk-print stole.
Here the scale of warring shapes and prints is attuned to the female shape underneath, so the result is a modern garment, not a modern sandwich board.
